7.02.text:
Distinguished judges, friends of the Faculty,
colleagues, students, good evening and welcome.

16.44.text:
I'm Sarah Worthington, and I really am delighted
to welcome you tonight to the Law Faculty

22.53.text:
for the 2015 Cambridge Freshfields Annual
Law Lecture.

28.50.text:
This is only the second in an annual series
of lectures generously sponsored by Freshfields

34.56.text:
and organised by the Cambridge Private Law
Centre through the Faculty, but it only takes

41.35.text:
two to make a tradition, doesn't it?
So one of the Centre's ambitions is to facilitate

48.28.text:
informed and challenging public debate about
some of the fundamental and significant legal

53.49.text:
issues which are facing us. So we are especially
delighted tonight to welcome Lord Hoffmann.

62.17.text:
He really is a judge who is well known for
his lively decisions and his willingness to

66.28.text:
break with convention, and it's my job to
introduce him.

70.66.text:
Now Lord Hoffmann really does need no introduction.
And he really does need no introduction, and

77.01.text:
I think there are very few people about whom
you could say that. I'm told that fame is

83.44.text:
when people recognise who you are from your
first name, and I know this will sound astonishingly

89.51.text:
over-familiar in a public lecture, but for
a lawyer, who else are you talking about when

95.70.text:
you talk about Lenny? Other than Lord Hoffmann.
So, but more seriously, why such fame? Why

104.39.text:
has he got such name recognition amongst lawyers?
So if I wear my Company Law hat, I would of

112.78.text:
course immediately recognise that Lord Hoffmann
has an especially large impact in Company

117.58.text:
Law, in very many areas, perhaps especially
in shareholder litigation, starting with O'Neil

123.87.text:
v Phillips, and you keep on going. But then
if I wear my commercial law hat, is there

130.76.text:
a practising lawyer, indeed is there a student,
whose not alert to the fact that Lord Hoffmann's

137.33.text:
restatement of orthodoxy in Investors Compensation,
managed to build a whole new industry in contract

145.61.text:
interpretation? And then, in Equity, all those
battles with Lord Millett, what fun!

155.43.text:
And the list goes on. In fact it goes on well
outside my field. So Lord Hoffmann has had

160.63.text:
a profound effect on human rights and those
difficult cases on terrorism. He has done

166.14.text:
the same in Intellectual Property Law, in
particular with patents. And thanks to an

171.63.text:
alert from one of my colleagues today, you
might note that the Supreme Court in their

176.14.text:
decision today in Michael v Chief Constable
of the South Wales Police Force has delivered

182.01.text:
a decision which I'm told presents the most
stunning re-affirmation of Lord Hoffmann's

187.96.text:
basic and rather restrictive approach to determining
whether a public body would be held liable

193.97.text:
in negligence for a failure to save someone
from harm.

199.41.text:
So, I think he's well known because his breadth
just sweeps across so many areas of law, and

209.24.text:
he has had such a profound impact on some
of the way we think about some of the fundamental

215.16.text:
issues.
But when you introduce people you are supposed

217.72.text:
to start at the beginning. Lord Hoffman was
born in Cape Town, educated at the University

222.45.text:
of Cape Town, and then attended that other
place, Queen's College Oxford, as a Rhodes

229.01.text:
Scholar. He studied for the BCL degree and
won the Vinerian Scholarship. For twelve years

234.53.text:
after that he was a fellow at the University
College in Oxford, where he is now an honorary

239.56.text:
fellow, and during that time he was also called
to the Bar at Gray's Inn, and quickly became

246.02.text:
one of the most sought-after, and I understand
one of the most highly priced, barristers

252.25.text:
of his generation. He was made a QC in 1977,
and a Judge shortly thereafter. He was a Law

259.96.text:
Lord from 1995 to 2009, and still serves as
a non-permanent Judge of the Court of Final

267.93.text:
Appeal of Hong Kong.
When he retired as a Law Lord, he didn't stop

272.10.text:
thinking like a lawyer. He immediately joined
a Centre for Commercial Law Studies at Queen

276.98.text:
Mary as an Honorary Professor of Intellectual
Property Law.

280.58.text:
But then you should say something more personal,
shouldn't you? And anyone who has watched

286.09.text:
any TV programmes on the House of Lords will
know that Lord Hoffmann has another side.

291.56.text:
He's a cyclist. He got to work in the House
of Lords on his bike every day. That's not

297.53.text:
all though. He's probably cycled more miles
in Europe - more kilometres in Europe - than

304.14.text:
any anyone who is not a professional cyclist.
He's also, so I'm given to understand, a voracious

310.74.text:
reader of novels. So he puts the rest of us
to shame who can barely manage our reading

314.85.text:
workload.
But enough, I think you get a flavour of the

318.97.text:
man, so without more ado I will handover to
Lord Hoffmann. His topic is 'Constitutionalism

325.08.text:
and Private Law'. Even the originality of
the title and the unlikely pairing of those

330.38.text:
ideas suggests we're in for a treat, and no
doubt for a few surprises. So Lord Hoffmann

336.35.text:
will speak for about 45 or 50 minutes, and
then he's happy to take questions.

339.18.text:
So, over to you Lord Hoffmann.
Well, it's a great pleasure and a privilege

362.15.text:
to be in Cambridge. This morning I was giving
a class in Patent Law in Oxford, where I'm

374.89.text:
seen more often. But, to be here is really
an honour.

380.94.text:
The advertised title of this lecture does
not give much away, so I shall say now that

388.64.text:
what I intend to discuss is what judges think
about when they are asked to change the common

396.89.text:
law. Many people think that it is not the
business of judges to change the law at all.

403.25.text:
One of the main purposes of the Code Napoleon
was to ensure that the whole of the civil

410.67.text:
law was written down in clear terms and confine
judges to applying the Code to the facts of

416.43.text:
the case. That is still the constitutional
theory in France, although experience has

425.21.text:
shown that it is not quite so simple. In England
there was a fiction that all the rules of

433.86.text:
common law had existed since the coronation
of Richard I in 1189 and that judges merely

442.03.text:
declared what it had always been, even if
this involved correcting an error by earlier

450.07.text:
judges. As a fiction it still exists and may
be said to serve a useful purpose. It supports

458.72.text:
the undoubted fact that changes in the law
by judicial decision, unlike most statutes,

468.92.text:
operate retrospectively. That is no fiction.
When the Supreme Court says that the law,

476.20.text:
which was previously thought to be entirely
in favour of the respondent, is actually in

481.65.text:
favour of the appellant, the respondent loses
the appeal, even though the facts of the case

491.52.text:
happened, by definition, before the Supreme
Court changed the law. Writers and judges

497.20.text:
have occasionally speculated about the possibility
of the Supreme Court assuming power to change

505.69.text:
the law only with prospective effect, it would
involve judges moving outside their normal

514.29.text:
business of deciding disputes between parties.
They would be saying to the successful party:

521.16.text:
'It is very public-spirited of you to have
brought this matter to our attention and we

527.90.text:
quite agree that the existing law is extremely
unjust, so we are going to change the law

533.62.text:
for the benefit of other people in the future,
but I am afraid you are going to lose because

538.03.text:
the unjust law was in force when you entered
into this transaction.' But the fact that

545.92.text:
a change in the law will operate retrospectively
is one of the matters which judges take into

556.22.text:
account in deciding whether it should be changed.
Even if they think a decision of their predecessors

564.12.text:
was wrong, the effect of a change on people
who entered into transactions on the assumption

571.69.text:
that it was right may be so unfair that it
would be better to leave things as they are.

579.63.text:
The judges can leave a rule of common law
unchanged even though they think it is wrong

586.41.text:
because judicial decisions are not the only
way in which the common law can be changed.

591.35.text:
It can be changed by Act of Parliament and
there are often reasons, like the retrospectivity

597.93.text:
of judicial decisions laying down the common
law, which may make it more desirable that

604.09.text:
Parliament should do so. That is obvious and
has been recognised by judges for a long time.

610.54.text:
But there are other reasons which are not
so well recognised, arising sometimes out

617.66.text:
of conceptual differences between rules of
statute and of common law and sometimes out

624.98.text:
of constitutional arguments based upon the
principle of the separation of powers. It

638.38.text:
is those which I propose to discuss tonight.
One of the most striking recent decisions

648.99.text:
changing a rule of common law was the decision
of the House of Lords in Kleinwort Benson

656.51.text:
v Lincoln City Council. The common law allows
a person who has mistakenly paid money that

665.28.text:
he did not owe to claim that it should be
repaid to him. It is unfair that the recipient

674.91.text:
should be allowed to take advantage of his
mistake. However, in the early nineteenth

681.47.text:
century it was decided that money could be
recovered only if it was paid under a mistake

688.39.text:
of fact. It could not be recovered if the
mistake was one of law. There was no logic

696.84.text:
in this distinction: whether the mistake was
one of fact or law, the person who paid did

704.51.text:
so because he thought the money was owing
when actually it was not. It was equally unfair

711.70.text:
that the recipient should be able to keep
money that was not due to him. The Law Commission

718.85.text:
recommended legislation to abolish the distinction.
However, it was treated as a rule of common

734.04.text:
law for nearly 200 years until the House of
Lords changed the law in the Kleinwort Benson

741.86.text:
case.
Why did the House of Lords feel able to say

745.75.text:
that a rule which had been assumed to be the
common law for so long was wrong and to change

751.76.text:
it with retrospective effect? Why did they
not leave it to Parliament to do for future

758.52.text:
cases? First, because the common law trades
in principles rather than arbitrary rules.

771.76.text:
The distinction between mistakes of fact and
law looked entirely unprincipled. Secondly,

781.17.text:
because there was no question of reliance.
Recipients of money that is not owing to them

789.87.text:
do not rely upon the fact that it was paid
under a mistake of law rather than fact. Of

796.53.text:
course they may share the mistaken view that
the money is due and go ahead and spend it,

807.94.text:
but that would be possible whatever the mistake
was about. There are special defences for

815.99.text:
people who have changed their position on
the basis of a mistaken assumption that the

819.34.text:
money was actually due to them, but they do
not depend upon the nature of the mistake.

826.50.text:
So the House of Lords thought it would be
unjust to leave parties who had in the past

832.82.text:
paid under a mistake of law without any remedy.
I now want to contrast the Kleinwort Benson

841.87.text:
case with another cases decided in the House
of Lords four years later: Fairchild v Glenhaven

850.39.text:
Funeral Services Ltd. This was the case about
victims of mesothelioma. This is a rare but

859.80.text:
fatal cancer, caused almost invariably by
ingestion of asbestos fibres. It has an incubation

869.54.text:
period of several decades so that the victims
tend to be people who worked with asbestos

877.18.text:
when its dangers were insufficiently appreciated.
In 2012 about 2,500 people died from mesothelioma,

890.67.text:
about 1.5% of cancer deaths in that year.
In many cases, their employers years earlier

900.31.text:
had been negligent in not taking precautions
against their coming into contact with asbestos.

908.67.text:
At common law, however, it is not enough to
prove that someone was negligent. You have

918.65.text:
to prove on a balance of probability that
his negligence caused your injury. But the

926.87.text:
problem about mesothelioma was that there
is no way of proving which asbestos fibres

937.00.text:
caused the disease. If you worked with asbestos
for several employer over the years, as most

946.78.text:
building and shipyard workers did, it could
have been caused by any of them. So the Court

953.98.text:
of Appeal decided that it was very unfortunate
but none of the employers could be made liable.

966.88.text:
The House of Lords decided that this was a
terrible injustice which they had to put right.

973.49.text:
So they created an exception in which it was
unnecessary to prove that the defendant caused

980.32.text:
the injury. It was sufficient to prove that
he substantially increased the chances of

988.40.text:
it happening. Statistically, you were more
likely to get the disease if you worked with

998.01.text:
asbestos for ten years than if you only did
so for three. So an employer who exposed you

1010.48.text:
to asbestos for a substantial time increased
the chances of your injury and the House of

1017.16.text:
Lords held that this was enough to make him
liable.

1020.15.text:
In principle, this was a revolutionary judgment.
The common law of negligence had always demanded

1030.98.text:
proof that the negligence had caused the injury.
It operated a binary system: you had either

1040.41.text:
caused it or you had not. If it was more than
50% likely that you had caused it, you were

1051.79.text:
taken definitely to have done so. If it was
50% or less, you had definitely not done so.

1059.15.text:
You recovered full compensation or none at
all. It is a crude but simple system. Why

1066.92.text:
did the House of Lords think it could change
the law?

1071.69.text:
The reason, of course, was that Fairchild
was a hard case. They say that hard cases

1077.18.text:
make bad law. The great difference between
Kleinwort Benson and Fairchild was that in

1085.89.text:
Kleinwort Benson one could say that, as a
matter of principle, the previous decisions

1092.05.text:
were wrong. It made no sense in the context
of recovering money paid by mistake to distinguish

1100.64.text:
between errors of fact and errors of law.
But the House of Lords in Fairchild did not

1107.28.text:
claim to be correcting a rule that was wrong
in principle. The general principle that you

1113.02.text:
had to prove causation on a balance of probability
was left intact. So the judges had to find

1120.59.text:
some principle upon which they were justified
in creating an exception. But they were unable

1129.21.text:
to do so. Should one say that the exception
should apply in all cases in which it was

1137.18.text:
impossible to prove which of two or more possible
causes was responsible? That would have been

1144.94.text:
far too wide. It would have destroyed the
general rule altogether. There are many cases

1151.22.text:
of medical negligence in which it is impossible
to prove that, but for some negligent act

1158.56.text:
on the part of the doctor, the patient would
have got better, or would not have got worse.

1166.73.text:
If it was enough to show that the doctor substantially
reduced the chances of getting better, the

1173.73.text:
£1 billion or so paid by the NHS last year
for clinical negligence claims would be considerably

1182.71.text:
increased.
The best we could do, and this includes myself,

1192.46.text:
was to say that the exception applied when
the injury was caused by the same agency.

1197.37.text:
In Fairchild, for example, it was definitely
caused by asbestos and only question was:

1207.36.text:
whose asbestos? It would not apply when, for
example, the cause of the disease was either

1215.40.text:
asbestos or smoking. But this was an unprincipled
decision which was almost comically exposed

1224.18.text:
in a later case in the Court of Appeal when
the claimant's cancer could have been caused

1229.12.text:
by smoking or by inhalation of chemicals from
dyestuffs with which he had been working.

1236.66.text:
The expert evidence showed that the chemical
substance in the dyes which might have caused

1240.69.text:
the disease was the same as that in the cigarettes.
This was an arbitrary distinction of ever

1246.88.text:
there was one.
I said in discussing Kleinwort Benson that

1254.35.text:
the common law trades in principles and not
in arbitrary rules. Kleinwort Benson was right

1260.98.text:
because it removed an arbitrary distinction
and restored the general principle. Fairchild

1266.08.text:
was wrong because it introduced an arbitrary
distinction into what had been a clear principle.

1272.88.text:
The judges recognised that they could not
limit the exception to mesothelioma. That

1277.76.text:
would have looked blatantly arbitrary. So
they tried to invent a distinction which looked

1282.92.text:
more like a principle but which came apart
in their hands.

1288.70.text:
Arbitrary distinctions in the law are often
necessary on pragmatic grounds. The voting

1295.89.text:
age is 18; you can't vote when you are 17
years and 11 months, even though you may have

1302.42.text:
a better knowledge of politics than someone
who is 19. It would not be practical to test

1307.50.text:
everyone's qualifications. Parliament can
do this and does it all the time. But judges

1316.76.text:
cannot. I think that in Fairchild we assumed
we alone could do something to put right an

1324.27.text:
injustice to mesothelioma victims. We did
not consider that Parliament might intervene.

1332.62.text:
But what happened afterwards is interesting.
The Fairchild case decided that if the negligence

1341.99.text:
of two or more employers had each substantially
increased the chances of a worker contracting

1350.33.text:
mesothelioma, each was liable. It did not
decide for how much. Were they each liable

1358.66.text:
for the whole of the damages, so that if one
was insolvent, the other had to pay the whole?

1364.79.text:
Or were they each liable in proportion to
their contribution to the chances of his getting

1370.88.text:
the disease? In a case two years after Fairchild,
the House of Lords decided that each was liable

1382.12.text:
for a proportion but not for the whole. That
meant that if one employer was insolvent,

1388.29.text:
the worker or his estate could not recover
his proportion of the damage.

1404.24.text:
This decision caused immediate protests from
the trade unions. The Government was sympathetic

1415.55.text:
and within three weeks an Act of Parliament
had been passed to reverse it. The Act made

1422.38.text:
all the employers liable jointly and severally
for the whole damage, did so retrospectively

1429.88.text:
and limited its application to mesothelioma.
This was the kind of thing which Parliament

1443.97.text:
could do but judges could not. I think that
if we had realised when we decided Fairchild

1455.80.text:
that Parliament would be willing to pounce
upon the problem in the way it later did,

1460.78.text:
we would have left well alone. We would have
said that it was a hard case but that the

1466.49.text:
common law could not be changed without damage
to an important general principle and the

1471.46.text:
creation of uncertainty about how far the
new exception extended. And we might have

1479.47.text:
recommended that Parliament deal with the
matter pragmatically by legislating specifically

1483.98.text:
for mesothelioma and, to be fair to the claimants
in our case, doing so retrospectively.

1492.80.text:
The Fairchild case illustrates the perils
of making changes in the common law which

1498.26.text:
cannot be justified on principle. But there
may be other, more constitutional, reasons

1509.59.text:
why judges should hold back. Sometimes it
will be because Parliament has already created

1517.68.text:
a system of rules which are a more practical
answer to the problem than anything which

1523.46.text:
the judges could devise. Sometimes it will
be that a proposed change in the law, for

1531.58.text:
example, to create a new head of liability,
will involve public expenditure and that it

1540.63.text:
is more appropriate that such expenditure
should be authorised by democratically elected

1548.23.text:
organs of government than by judges. The Fairchild
rule itself opened the way to a case which

1556.25.text:
raised an issue of this kind. Gregg v Scott
was a case in which a doctor had been negligent

1564.44.text:
in telling a patient that a lump under his
arm was benign instead of referring him to

1570.70.text:
hospital to have it checked. In fact it was
found a year later to be cancerous and the

1578.57.text:
judge found, not surprisingly, that having
cancer had reduced the patient's expectation

1584.52.text:
of life. The question, however, was whether
it would have made any difference if it had

1591.41.text:
been diagnosed earlier. The judge found on
a balance of probability that it had made

1598.10.text:
no difference. There was, he said, after looking
at epidemiological statistics, a 40% chance

1605.53.text:
that it would have made a difference and under
the law's binary system, that meant it had

1612.01.text:
to be taken as having made no difference.
In the House of Lords it was submitted that

1619.23.text:
we ought to extend a version of the Fairchild
principle to all cases of medical negligence

1626.84.text:
and award the patient 40% of the damages he
would have recovered if he had been wholly

1634.54.text:
successful. This would have been a huge change
in the common law and, furthermore, would

1638.75.text:
have enormously increased the liabilities
of the National Health Service. If such a

1643.94.text:
change in the law was desirable, it should
be made by Parliament and not by judges. Fortunately,

1651.86.text:
by a majority of 3 to 2, the proposed change
in the law was rejected. It was a very close-run

1659.05.text:
thing.
I turn next to those cases in which the courts

1665.34.text:
should not make changes in the common law
because the ground which a change would cover

1672.73.text:
is already occupied, or should be occupied,
by statute. I shall take two examples from

1679.83.text:
the law of nuisance.
The law of nuisance goes back to mediaeval

1685.93.text:
times. It is concerned with a certain species
of what economists call externalities, i.e.

1696.73.text:
either the involuntary imposition of some
of the costs of an activity upon other people

1705.99.text:
or the conferment upon other people of benefits
which they have not paid for. Nuisance is

1715.87.text:
concerned with the first kind of externality
in connection with the use of land. The best

1721.81.text:
example is the great mid-Victorian case of
St Helen's Smelting Company v Tipping , in

1728.00.text:
which an alkali company in Lancashire polluted
the atmosphere to such an extent that it was

1735.03.text:
actually dumping chemicals upon the surrounding
land. The result was to impose some of the

1742.22.text:
costs of the business on other people. The
House of Lords decided that the law of nuisance

1754.84.text:
allowed the other landowners to claim compensation.
In those days, of course, there was no planning

1760.99.text:
control and the law of nuisance was the only
remedy available to prevent landowners from

1767.25.text:
doing what they liked upon their land.
A comprehensive system of planning control

1776.48.text:
was introduced by the Town and Country Planning
Act 1948 and the 1990 version was in force

1785.88.text:
when Hunter v Canary Wharf Ltd came before
the House of Lords in 1997. The tower of Canary

1795.64.text:
Wharf, clad in stainless steel, interfered
with television reception from the transmitter

1804.00.text:
at Crystal Palace. Many houses in Poplar which
lay in its electro-magnetic shadow could not

1821.12.text:
receive any signal at all. This continued
for three or four years until the construction

1829.72.text:
of a relay transmitter to the north. They
claimed compensation under the law of nuisance,

1839.11.text:
saying that the building had interfered with
the use of their houses.

1845.98.text:
To allow such a claim would have been an extension
of the law. There had never been an action

1852.49.text:
for nuisance if you kept yourself to yourself
and simply constructed a building on your

1858.77.text:
land. A neighbour could not complain that
you had interrupted his view or blocked the

1864.91.text:
flow of air or even darkened his windows,
although there is a rather anomalous rule

1872.60.text:
by which you can acquire a right to light
if your building has been up for more than

1880.11.text:
20 years. If you cannot complain of interference
with light or view, why should you be entitled

1886.57.text:
to complain of interference with television?
And yet, being deprived of television is in

1894.30.text:
today's society a serious matter. Why should
it not be regarded as a cost of putting up

1903.35.text:
the building, which should be borne by the
developers hoping to make a profit from letting

1908.40.text:
the office space? That was the argument for
extending the law.

1916.93.text:
So far as I was concerned, at any rate, part
of the reason for not doing so was the existence

1921.83.text:
of planning control. A planning inquiry gives
the planning authority an opportunity to hear

1929.74.text:
the objections of the neighbourhood. It can
require the developer to enter into an agreement

1939.56.text:
under section 106 of the Act to take steps
to prevent inconvenience to others; for example,

1946.35.text:
to pay for the construction of a relay transmitter
before the building is completed. Statutory

1953.97.text:
planning control seems to me a much more effective
mechanism for avoiding such externalities

1961.94.text:
than having individual actions for compensation
brought by hundred of householders in the

1968.45.text:
neighbourhood. In the Canary Wharf case, however,
the difficulty was that Parliament had altogether

1976.72.text:
suspended the application of planning control
to the Isle of Dogs. It was so anxious to

1984.58.text:
regenerate the Docklands that it declared
the area an enterprise zone in which landowners

1992.07.text:
were free from any restriction. They could
build what they liked without having to get

1997.57.text:
planning permission. So the television reception
of the householders of Poplar was sacrificed

2004.42.text:
to the greater good of developing Docklands.
But those special circumstances were not a

2012.17.text:
reason for a change in the common law which
would have to apply where planning control

2020.32.text:
existed. And one must not forget that in addition
to negative externalities like interference

2028.31.text:
with television, there were positive externalities
which conferred upon the householders other

2033.90.text:
benefits which they had not paid for. The
construction of the Docklands Light Railway

2038.45.text:
and other infrastructure projects at public
expense and the consequent revival of the

2043.73.text:
neighbourhood increased the value of their
houses.

2048.70.text:
If the statutory system of planning was a
relevant circumstance which the House of Lords

2057.07.text:
in the Canary Wharf case took into account
in deciding not to extend the law, in the

2064.16.text:
case of Marcic v Thames Water Utilities the
statutory scheme was decisive. Marcic was

2072.48.text:
a case about sewers. Until they were recently
privatised, sewers were a public utility and

2080.08.text:
subject to a statutory scheme. An important
element of that scheme, going back into the

2087.03.text:
19th century, was that anyone had the right
to connect his premises into a public sewer.

2096.66.text:
From a public health point of view, it was
desirable that he should do. But it gave rise

2102.37.text:
to a problem if so many people emptied their
sewage into the foul sewers that they became

2114.05.text:
overloaded. In time of heavy rain the sewers
would back up and deposit foul sewage in people's

2122.85.text:
gardens. That was what happened to Mr Marcic,
who had a house in Stanmore. He had to build

2136.24.text:
his own flood defences to keep the sewage
from coming into his house. So he made a claim

2142.86.text:
in nuisance against the sewage company, saying
that the inadequacy of their sewers had interfered

2149.61.text:
with his use of his property.
The company had no control over the quantity

2157.10.text:
of sewage which went into their sewers. So
the complaint was not about anything which

2165.88.text:
the company had done. It was said that, faced
with increasing use, it should have done something

2172.01.text:
positive to enlarge the sewers.
The ancient rule of common law was that liability

2180.68.text:
in nuisance required you to have done some
positive act causing damage to another landowner.

2186.55.text:
You were not liable from simply allowing nature
to take its course. In the last sixty or seventy

2195.20.text:
years, however, that rule has been thought
slightly too restrictive. There are some exceptional

2201.84.text:
cases in which people have been required to
take some action to prevent a dangerous situation

2208.21.text:
on their land, which they had not themselves
created, from spreading to a neighbour. A

2216.26.text:
farmer in Australia was held liable for not
preventing the spread of a fire which had

2221.92.text:
been started by lightning. The National Trust
was liable for not doing something to prevent

2227.73.text:
eroded rocks from tumbling onto the next property.
But these are very unusual forms of liability,

2236.91.text:
particularly because they require the court
to take into account what the particular defendant

2244.94.text:
could have done. The normal rule about liability
for things you do is that there is an single

2253.91.text:
standard of reasonable behaviour for everyone.
If you do not have the resources or skill

2260.15.text:
to meet that standard, you ought not to do
it at all. But that would obviously be unfair

2267.44.text:
when the complaint is that the defendant simply
failed to do something. It needs an inquiry

2273.22.text:
into what he in particular could have done;
what resources he had available. That may

2276.92.text:
not be an easy matter. However, if it is a
difficult question between neighbours, it

2283.97.text:
is a much more difficult question when it
comes to whether a sewage company should have

2291.73.text:
built more or bigger sewers. In order to do
so, they will have to charge the public more.

2301.91.text:
Would it be fair for the householders of Greenwich
to have to pay more for their sewerage to

2310.19.text:
enable more sewers to be constructed in Stanmore?
Because these are complicated questions, Parliament

2318.82.text:
has for more than a hundred years entrusted
them to administrators. Noawadays, if your

2329.19.text:
local sewer is inadequate, you can complain
to the Director-General of Water Services.

2335.51.text:
He will then consider whether something ought
to be done. He will take into account the

2341.03.text:
severity of the problem, how it ranks in priority
compared with other sewers that need to be

2349.67.text:
build or enlarged, what it will cost, whether
that will mean putting up water rates and

2355.10.text:
so on. That is obviously not an exercise a
court could undertake in litigation between

2364.25.text:
The House of Lords therefore decided that
the question of whether the law of nuisance

2370.43.text:
should be extended to cover Mr Marcic's case
could not be decided without regard to the

2375.94.text:
existence of statutory regulation. That seemed
to deal with matter much better than anything

2382.69.text:
the common law could achieve.
My last example of the relationship between

2394.80.text:
the roles of the judiciary and the legislature
in changing the law is the extraordinary story

2401.37.text:
of the economic torts, that is to say, torts
which consist of causing the claimant purely

2408.62.text:
financial loss. Until the mid-nineteenth century
they hardly existed. There had been two cases

2417.94.text:
in the seventeenth and eighteenth in which
judges appeared to think that tradesmen had

2424.62.text:
caused loss to rivals by exceeding the bounds
of fair competition: there was a seventeenth

2434.18.text:
century case in which a quarryman at Oxford
made death threats against anyone who traded

2439.37.text:
with a rival and another a century later in
which the master of a ship trading on the

2447.53.text:
west coast of Africa fired a cannon at a canoe
bringing good to sell to a rival ship. But

2458.77.text:
the obscure reports in which these cases were
reported said little about the principle on

2464.51.text:
which they were decided. In Lumley v. Gye
, however, the common law went a great deal

2473.20.text:
further. In this famous case, Mr Lumley, the
manager of Her Majesty's Theatre, engaged

2481.20.text:
Miss Johanna Wagner, a famous soprano and
Richard Wagner's niece, to sign Donna Anna

2488.04.text:
in Don Giovanni and a couple of other roles.
Mr Gye, manager of the Covent Garden Theatre,

2497.09.text:
not yet the Royal Opera House, offered her
better terms, so she broke her contract and

2504.02.text:
did not appear. The Court of Queen's Bench
decided by a majority that inducing a party

2513.68.text:
to break a contract was a tort. The only precedent
for such a claim was the mediaeval action

2521.45.text:
for poaching a servant, which was based partly
on the theory that one had a proprietary interest

2529.32.text:
in one's servant and partly upon the economic
needs of landowners arising out of the acute

2537.51.text:
shortage caused by the Black Death. As in
the case of mediaeval labourers, the judges

2545.86.text:
in Lumley v Gye felt that it went beyond the
bounds of fair competition to poach a famous

2551.21.text:
opera singer who had already signed up for
a rival.

2556.10.text:
What was the general common law principle
which the case represented? At the time, it

2561.36.text:
was not easy to say. Mr Willes QC, who had
been on the losing side, maintained for the

2569.41.text:
rest of his life that the case had been wrongly
decided. The judges in Lumley v Gye could

2579.80.text:
not have declared that the Statute of Labourers
1351 was being extended to opera singers or

2586.37.text:
even to people offering cultural services
to members of the middle classes like themselves.

2592.87.text:
Parliament could have done this, but not the
courts in their interpretation of the common

2597.58.text:
law.
Did it express a principle of unfair competition?

2602.34.text:
It looks as though that was what the judges
had in mind. You may offer customers a better

2607.75.text:
deal than your competitors, but not when you
know that they have already signed up to a

2614.33.text:
binding contract with someone else. That is
going too far. But the common law, unlike

2617.59.text:
for example German law , knows no general
theory of unfair competition of which this

2625.55.text:
could be a species. The common law has a few
specific principles of unfair competition,

2631.80.text:
like the tort of passing off: you may not
deceive the public by pretending that your

2637.87.text:
goods are those of a competitor. This is safe
ground for the common law, deception being

2641.75.text:
something that judges are used to dealing
with. It does not raise any difficult questions

2647.35.text:
of economics or public interest. I suppose
the same may be said about the ancient cases

2653.22.text:
about violence against a rival's customers.
Presumably the judges in Lumley v Gye thought

2660.09.text:
that inducing a breach of contract with a
competitor was crossing a bright line which

2666.76.text:
would be easy for judges for the judges to
police. But I doubt they thought very hard

2673.44.text:
about it; the judgments contain some general
statements that there might be cases in which

2678.93.text:
inducing a breach of contract could be justified
but no illustrations of what they might be.

2685.91.text:
But the Court simply fastened upon the fact
that any breach of contract was an unlawful

2690.09.text:
act, a violation of the rule that people should
perform their bargains, and that Mr Gye had

2695.27.text:
deliberately induced such a breach to profit
at the expense of his rival.

2700.39.text:
For many years Lumley v Gye remained a curiosity,
a controversial anomaly. No one was quite

2708.35.text:
sure how far it went. Thirty years later,
when the Court of Appeal in Bowen v Hall decided

2715.71.text:
by a majority to approve it, Lord Coleridge
said that it had never previously been applied.

2722.64.text:
What made the rule in Lumley v Gye explode
into public life was the rise of the trade

2730.25.text:
union movement, which had led a shadowy existence
of semi-illegality until Disraeli's Conspiracy

2739.71.text:
and Protection of Property Act 1875. The ultimate
bargaining weapon of a nineteenth century

2748.25.text:
trade union was a strike, either against the
employer with whom they were in dispute or

2758.58.text:
against a customer or supplier whom they wanted
to compel to put pressure upon a recalcitrant

2764.39.text:
employer. A strike often involved breaches
of the strikers' contracts of employment,

2772.43.text:
although not always, as the plaintiff in Allen
v Flood discovered when he lost his case in

2779.64.text:
the House of Lords on what must have seemed
to most people the highly technical point

2784.67.text:
that his fellow employees who threatened to
strike unless he was sacked had no contracts

2789.32.text:
of employment. They just signed on from day
to day. The question which arose in the last

2801.19.text:
quarter of the nineteenth century was whether
the courts would transfer the rule in Lumley

2806.50.text:
v Gye from the context of competing traders
to that of industrial relations, where the

2814.78.text:
economic considerations were entirely different.
Temperton v Russell in 1893 was the crucial

2823.28.text:
case in which Lord Esher MR enthusiastically
embraced Lumley v Gye as a weapon against

2832.15.text:
the trade unions. His judgment makes no secret
of his political views and it put the courts

2839.90.text:
and the unions on a collision course in a
series of highly politicised cases in the

2848.49.text:
last decade of the nineteenth century and
the early years of the twentieth.

2855.67.text:
The difficulty was that although inducing
a breach of contract might be a bright line

2862.99.text:
(although perhaps not always a very logical
one) in cases of competition between traders,

2868.91.text:
which would seldom raise questions of justification,
such questions were very much to the fore

2877.87.text:
in cases about industrial relations. You could
not regulate strikes by law without having

2886.73.text:
a political and economic view about the circumstances
in which a strike would be justified. Not

2894.76.text:
only were judges unqualified to make such
decisions; the questions were so politically

2899.44.text:
charged that it was constitutionally inappropriate
that they should do so. In the Mogul Steamship

2909.16.text:
case , decided a year before Temperton v Russell,
the House of Lords emphatically declared that

2915.75.text:
it was incapable of laying down a general
principle of unfair competition between traders.

2921.50.text:
The shipowner defendants in the Mogul case
had done everything which nowadays would bring

2927.76.text:
down upon them huge fines from the competition
authority. They had formed a cartel, lowered

2934.75.text:
prices to drive out competition and then raised
them again and so forth. The House of Lords

2941.26.text:
said this was perfectly lawful. That was entirely
reasonable. Their view was that it was for

2948.83.text:
Parliament, rather than the common law, to
create a system for dealing with restrictive

2953.47.text:
practices and unfair competition, as it eventually
did in the Restrictive Trade Practices Act

2958.52.text:
1956.
In the case of industrial relations, however,

2964.10.text:
the courts plunged into the fray. They refused
to engage in economic questions of justification.

2971.41.text:
In the South Wales Miners case in 1905, the
union attempted to justify a strike by saying

2979.01.text:
that it was in the legitimate interests of
their members, who were being paid miserable

2984.82.text:
wages. The House of Lords would have none
of it. Liability depended upon breach of contract

2991.96.text:
and nothing but the breach of contract. The
result was that apart from cases in which

2998.50.text:
judges could apply moral views which did not
involve questions of politics or economics,

3003.83.text:
like the man who persuaded chorus girls to
desert in breach of contract to rescue them

3008.45.text:
from prostitution , the question of justification
disappeared from view.

3015.59.text:
If ever there was an example of the law of
unintended consequences, it was the decision

3020.58.text:
of the Court of Queen's Bench to give Mr Lumley
a remedy against Mr Gye. The judges who thought

3025.21.text:
there should be a remedy because Mr Gye had
not behaved like a gentleman could not have

3029.73.text:
foreseen that fifty years later it would form
the basis for a political storm which did

3037.19.text:
much to give rise to the growth of the Labour
Party and to bring down the government in

3042.26.text:
the election of 1905, after which the unions
were given protection by the Trade Disputes

3048.52.text:
Act 1906.
The political pressures under which the law

3053.95.text:
evolved in the late nineteenth century also
produced illogicalities. For example, was

3060.76.text:
the rule confined to inducing breach of contract
or was that just one example of a wider tort

3067.99.text:
of interfering with economic relations? In
Temperton v Russell Lord Esher, in an expansive

3076.75.text:
mood, said he could see no difference between
inducing the target employer's suppliers to

3082.66.text:
break their contracts and inducing them not
to enter into such contracts. In both cases

3090.52.text:
the purpose of the strike is to use action
against the supplier to put economic pressure

3095.72.text:
upon the employer. It is hard not to sympathise
with Lord Esher, because he was obviously

3102.17.text:
right. In the opera world, it may make sense
to treat the signing of the contract as the

3109.19.text:
line you may not cross. Once you know that
Miss Wagner is under contract, you may not

3114.16.text:
offer her a larger fee or a better dressing
room. It is hard to think of what would be

3119.21.text:
regarded as justification for doing so. In
the world of labour relations, however, the

3124.99.text:
question of whether there is justification
for applying economic pressure is more important

3130.84.text:
than whether there was a contract or not.
What Lord Esher did not recognise was that

3136.27.text:
his sound instinct about the real issue did
not necessarily lead to the conclusion that

3142.26.text:
the trade unionists should be liable whether
there was a contract or not. It might be that

3147.32.text:
they should not be liable in either case and
whether or not they should was essentially

3150.56.text:
a political question for Parliament to decide.
However, a few years later a majority in the

3154.67.text:
House of Lords in Allen v Flood , who did
not share Lord Esher's political views, saw

3161.40.text:
insistence on a breach of contract as a way
of cutting back the application of Lumley

3167.98.text:
v Gye to trade union disputes. So it did,
but it left the law in a highly illogical

3173.80.text:
state.
The Trade Disputes Act 1906 drew the teeth

3179.68.text:
of Lumley v Gye in the area of industrial
relations. The turbulent labour relations

3190.67.text:
of the sixties and seventies gave rise to
the judicial invention of some new economic

3196.45.text:
torts, namely intimidation and causing loss
by unlawful means, which were a muted reprise

3205.58.text:
of the events of the late nineteenth and early
twentieth centuries. But the role of the common

3211.46.text:
law in this area was entirely extinguished
by Mrs Thatcher's trade union legislation

3220.62.text:
in the early eighties. Since then, no political
party has shown any appetite for allowing

3230.69.text:
the possibility of further judge-made law.
Unfair competition, as the House of Lords

3237.52.text:
had recognised in the Mogul case more than
a century ago, is also not an area suitable

3241.99.text:
for judge-made law. It also involves questions
of policy and economics which are more appropriately

3247.86.text:
decided by Parliament or by statutory machinery.
When the scope of the economic torts was considered

3258.35.text:
by the House of Lords in OBG v Allan in 2008,
the general approach was to restrict their

3266.18.text:
scope as far as respect for precedent would
allow. So inducing breach of contract is now,

3274.58.text:
perhaps uniquely in the law of tort, a tort
of specific intent; you must intend a specific

3281.07.text:
consequence, namely the breach of a contract
of which you have knowledge. It does not matter

3284.96.text:
that you were careless or stupid in being
unaware there was a contact. Furthermore,

3289.74.text:
there must have been an actual breach; cases
which created liability for interference with

3295.18.text:
the performance of a contract, not amounting
to a breach, were overruled. The tort of causing

3304.67.text:
loss by unlawful means was pruned back to
its roots in the old cases about death threats

3311.04.text:
to customers: you must have done something
unlawful to a third party which affected his

3317.51.text:
ability to deal with the claimant. In effect
the House recognised that in Lumley v Gye

3324.59.text:
the judges had made a mistake, by entering
a field better left to Parliament.

3332.03.text:
In this lecture I have dwelt upon the cases
in which the courts have unwisely trespassed

3339.43.text:
upon ground better left to Parliament. But
the opposite is sometimes also true. The common

3346.04.text:
law consists of general principles of great
flexibility which have been applied over centuries

3351.42.text:
in many situations recorded in the Law Reports.
In some cases, the introduction of legislation

3362.34.text:
covering the same ground is like a bull in
a china shop. Consider, for example, the Social

3370.98.text:
Action, Responsibility and Heroism Bill, presently
about to return to the House of Commons. It

3386.70.text:
requires that in an action for negligence,
the court must have regard to whether the

3392.89.text:
defendant was acting for the benefit of society,
demonstrated a generally responsible attitude

3399.65.text:
towards protecting the safety and interests
of others, or was acting heroically by intervening

3406.25.text:
in an emergency to assist an individual in
danger. All these are things that, as a matter

3416.16.text:
of principle, any court would already take
into account. So what are we to make of the

3423.57.text:
Act? Does it change the law? What was the
mischief, in the traditional phrase, which

3431.12.text:
it was meant to correct? It seems to have
been declaratory: a Parliamentary statement

3439.49.text:
to reassure readers of the Daily Mail that
judges would, contrary to their supposed previous

3448.02.text:
practice, have regard to such matters. The
trouble with such political interventions

3453.75.text:
in the common law is that they run the risk
of causing confusion by being taken seriously.

3463.13.text:
The adaptation of the law to the needs of
justice and to changing conditions is a partnership

3474.10.text:
between the judiciary and the legislature,
which requires some sensitivity on the part

3479.34.text:
of both branches of government; a recognition
by the one that there are areas in which change,

3486.65.text:
however desirable, is best left to the other.
W.S. Gilbert said of the role of the House

3493.74.text:
of Lords in defeating Napoleon that they,
"did nothing in particular, and did it very

3499.09.text:
well". And that is something I can sometimes
recommend. Sometimes to the Courts, and sometimes
